Johnson . 315 Cooper argues that in terms of impact and ambition, only the New Deal and the Great Society rival the domestic accomplishments of Wilson's presidency. 317 Many of Wilson's accomplishments, including the Federal Reserve, the Federal Trade Commission, the graduated income tax, and labor laws, continued to influence the United States long after Wilson's death. 315 Many conservatives have attacked Wilson for his role in expanding the federal government . 318 319 320 In 2018, conservative columnist George Will wrote in The Washington Post that Theodore Roosevelt and Wilson were the "progenitors of today's imperial presidency ." 321 Wilson's idealistic foreign policy, which came to be known as Wilsonianism , also cast a long shadow over American foreign policy , and Wilson's League of Nations influenced the development of the United Nations . 315 Saladin Ambar writes that Wilson was "the first statesman of world stature to speak out not only against European imperialism but against the newer form of economic domination sometimes described as 'informal imperialism.'" 322 Notwithstanding his accomplishments in office, Wilson has received criticism for his record on race relations and civil liberties, for his interventions in Latin America, and for his failure to win ratification of the Treaty of Versailles. 323 322 Despite his southern roots and record at Princeton, Wilson became the first Democrat to receive widespread support from the African American community in a presidential election. 324 Wilson's African-American supporters, many of whom had crossed party lines to vote for him in 1912, found themselves bitterly disappointed by the Wilson presidency, his decision to allow the imposition of Jim Crow within the federal bureaucracy in particular. 303 Ross Kennedy writes that Wilson's support of segregation complied with predominant public opinion. 325 A. Scott Berg argues Wilson accepted segregation as part of a policy to "promote racial progress... by shocking the social system as little as possible." 326 The ultimate result of this policy would be unprecedented levels of segregation within the federal bureaucracy and far fewer opportunities for employment and promotion being open to African-Americans than before. 327 Historian Kendrick Clements argues "Wilson had none of the crude, vicious racism of James K. Vardaman or Benjamin R. Tillman , but he was insensitive to African-American feelings and aspirations." 328 In the wake of the Charleston church shooting , some individuals demanded the removal of Wilson's name from institutions affiliated with Princeton due to his stance on race. 329 330 As of 2021, Wilson remains the only U.S. president to earn either a PH.D or a doctorate. 331 Memorials The Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars in Washington, D.C., is named for Wilson, and the Princeton School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton was named for Wilson until Princeton's Board of Trustees voted to remove Wilson's name in 2020. 333 The Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation is a non-profit that provides grants for teaching fellowships. The Woodrow Wilson Foundation was established to honor Wilson's legacy, but it was terminated in 1993. One of Princeton's six residential colleges was originally named Wilson College . 333 Numerous schools, including several high schools , bear Wilson's name. Several streets, including the Rambla Presidente Wilson in Montevideo, Uruguay , have been named for Wilson. The USS Woodrow Wilson , a Lafayette-class submarine , was named for Wilson. Other things named for Wilson include the Woodrow Wilson Bridge between Prince George's County, Maryland and Virginia , and the Palais Wilson , which serves as the temporary headquarters of the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights in Geneva until 2023 at the end of leasing. 334 Monuments to Wilson include the Woodrow Wilson Monument in Prague . 335 Popular culture In 1944, 20th Century Fox released Wilson , a biopic about the 28th President. Starring Alexander Knox and directed by Henry King , Wilson is considered an "idealistic" portrayal of the title character. The movie was a personal passion project of studio President and famed producer Darryl F. Zanuck , who was a deep admirer of Wilson. The movie received mostly praise from critics and Wilson supporters and scored 336 337 ten Academy Awards nominations, winning five. 338 Despite its popularity amongst elites, Wilson was a box office bomb , incurring an almost $2 million loss for the studio. 339 The movie's failure is said to have had a deep and long lasting impact on Zanuck and no attempt has been made by any major studio since to create a motion picture based around the life of Woodrow Wilson. 340 Works Electoral history of Woodrow Wilson Notes ^ Though a handful of elite, Northern schools did admit African-American students, at the time, most colleges refused to accept black students. Most African-American college students attended black colleges and universities such as Howard University . 54 ^ In December 1913, Wilson inaugurated the tradition of delivering the annual State of the Union address before a joint session of Congress. From 1801 to 1912, presidents had submitted an annual message to Congress in writing. 111 ^ House and Wilson fell out during the Paris Peace Conference, and House no longer played a role in the administration after June 1919. 225 ^ contrary to popular belief, neither the production nor consumption of alcohol was prohibited. Industrial alcohol, which is not safe for human consumption, continued to be widely manufactured.
